abstract: Saturday Profile of Mohamed Soltan, American who was arrested in 2013 by Egyptian police along with many other suspected Islamic or liberal dissidents; Falls Church, Va, resident, who spent 21 months in Egyptian prison, has become advocate for tens of thousands still languishing in Egypt’s prisons, positing that mass incarceration nurtures anti-Americanism and Islamic radicalization.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed Soltan, who had been arrested at an Islamist protest, has argued to American officials that Egypt’s mass incarcerations are radicalizing youth and damaging United States interests.

headline.main: U.S. Citizen, Once Held in Egypt’s Crackdown, Becomes Voice for Inmates
headline.print_headline: Once Held in Egypt, Now a Voice for Inmates

snippet: Mohamed Soltan, who had been arrested at an Islamist protest, has argued to American officials that Egypt’s mass incarcerations are radicalizing youth and damaging United States interests.

keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
